Schedule of Events, Abstracts and Profiles | conference = 1st US-Asian Demonstration and Assessment of Micro Aerial Vehicle (MAV) and Unmanned Ground Vehicle (UGV) Technology | publisher = National Aerospace Laboratories, ADRDE, US Army RDECOM |date=March 10–15, 2008 | location = (also accessible on the internet at: http://www.nal.res.in/MAV08/MAV-pdf/mavabstracts.pdf) |accessdate=2009-03-22 | volume = | pages = 70 | isbn = }} He performed similar duties for the U.S. Army in defining the 1st US-European Micro Air Vehicle Competition/Demonstration in [[Garmisch]] [[Germany]] in 2005.{{cite news|url=http://aeromav.free.fr/MAV05/aeromav/vitae/|title=MAV05 organizers' vitae from remaining documents at MAV05 website|accessdate=2009-03-19|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720220238/http://aeromav.free.fr/MAV05/aeromav/vitae/ |archivedate=2011-07-20|df=}} He created the short course, ''21st Century Aerial Robotics'',{{cite news|url=http://www.aiaa.org/Participate/Uploads/ATIO2006%20Briefing.ppt|title=Ref. to 21st Century Aerial Robotics by Robert Michelson and Laurence Newcome on page 2 of this April 2006 AIAA ATIO-2006 Status Briefing|accessdate=2009-03-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616194344/http://www.aiaa.org/Participate/Uploads/ATIO2006%20Briefing.ppt|archivedate=2011-06-16|df=}}{{cite news|url=http://www-cse.uta.edu/~reyes/research/reyes_biography.htm|title=Ref. to September 14, 2003 offering of "21st Century Aerial Robotics" by Robert Michelson and Laurence "Nuke" Newcomb at the AIAA Unmanned Unlimited conference in San Diego.|accessdate=2009-03-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080827215901/http://www-cse.uta.edu/~reyes/research/reyes_biography.htm|archivedate=August 27, 2008|df=}} and the digital signal processing lecture/demonstrations in “Principals of Modern Radar” at the Georgia Institute of Technology. He is also creator and organizer of the annual [[International Aerial Robotics Competition]].{{cite book |last = Toon (editor) |first = John |title = AUVSI/Georgia Tech Press Release, "Robots that Fly: College Teams Demonstrate New Technology in First-of-its-Kind Competition July 29" |publisher = The Georgia Tech Research Institute |date = 15 July 1991 |location = Atlanta, Georgia USA |pages = 15 |url = http://www.gtri.gatech.edu/gtri75/files/media/NR_1991_7_15b.pdf |doi = |id = mirror site: http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/BioPict/GTRI-NR_1991_7_15b.pdf |isbn = }} Before joining the staff of the Georgia Tech Research Institute he participated in design and endo-atmospheric flight testing of computer-controlled space-based radar ocean surveillance systems while employed by the [[U.S. Naval Research Laboratory|Naval Research Laboratory]] in Washington, D.C. Michelson is listed in various editions of ''Who’s Who in Engineering'', ''Who’s Who in America'', and the 23rd edition of ''[[Marquis Who's Who|Who’s Who in the World]]''. He is the author of over 90 reports, journal papers, and book chapters. [[File:IFTEC-Pneumatic Launcher.png|thumb|right|200px|Indirect Fire Terminal Effects Cue pneumatic launcher developed by Michelson for US Army CDEC.]] ===Project director=== While at the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, Michelson worked on radar-based ocean surveillance systems and flew hardware test missions on a [[Lockheed Constellation|Lockheed Warning Star PO-1W Super Constellation]].{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/PastProjects/Michelson-NRL-activity.GIF|title=Robert Michelson's Research Activities Aerospace Radar Branch - U.S. Naval Research Laboratory |accessdate=2009-05-15}} In 1974 Michelson began work at the Georgia Tech Research Institute, where he got his first contract when an entry-level engineer (Research Engineer I). This first project involved methods to electronically track the endangered species Trichechus ''manatus'' ([[West Indian Manatee]]) in the waters around the [[Kennedy Space Center]].{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/PastProjects/Auto-ManateeTracking.GIF|title=Automated Tracking of the Florida Manatee (Trichechus ''manatus'') |accessdate=2009-05-15}} Michelson directed over 30 major research projects during his career at the Institute. In 1979 Michelson directed the Army's Indirect Fire Simulation effort conducted for Combat Development and Experimentation Command (CDEC).{{cite book | last = Michelson | first = Robert |author2=R. Brooks |author3=F. Williams | title = An Indirect-Fire Terminal Effects Simulator | publisher = Proceedings of the 3rd Inter-service/Industry Training Equipment Conference | date = December 1981 | location = Orlando, Florida | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} Michelson directed a [[DARPA|Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA) program to show feasibility of a non-line-of-sight radio-acoustic sensor for bending radar signals using the Bragg principle to detect obstacle-masked targets (essentially making radars look around corners).{{cite book | last = Michelson | first = Robert |author2=K.A. Ahuja |author3=J.A. Scheer | title = Feasibility of Applying Radio-Acoustic Techniques to Non Line-of-Sight Sensing | publisher = 15th AIAA Aeroacoustics Conference | date = October 25–27, 1993 | location = Long Beach, CA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = |display-authors=etal}} He also directed a program to evaluate ground penetration radar for detection of buried natural gas leaks in urban utility systems.{{cite book | last = Michelson | first = Robert |author2=J.A. Scheer |author3=L. Gostin | title = Remote Detection of Natural Gas Leaks from Buried Utility Pipes by Electromagnetic Means | publisher = Georgia Institute of Technology | date = June 1986 | location = Atlanta, Georgia USA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = Final Report, Contract No. GRI-50084-252-112 (subcontract to the Philadelphia Electric Company; prime to the Gas Research Institute) | isbn = |display-authors=etal}} During 1981, Michelson directed a program for the automated noninvasive testing of captured foreign threat assets. This system developed by Michelson's design team remained in use by a foreign power for nearly a decade. Other radar test devices were also developed by Michelson for U.S. military test and evaluation purposes within the United States, including a program to develop a Ka-band Linear Electronics Countermeasure Source (KABLES) for use in testing U.S. Army millimeter wave assets.{{cite book | last = Butterworth | first = Clark |author2=R.C. Michelson | title = Ka-Band Linear ECM Source (KABLES) | publisher = Georgia Institute of Technology | date = June 1984 | location = Atlanta, Georgia USA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = Final Report No. F33615-81-C-1530-F | isbn = |display-authors=etal}}{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/PastProjects/KABLES.GIF |title=KABLES |accessdate=2009-05-18}} [[File:Dragon Stalker Drone.png|thumb|right|200px|Compound [[ducted fan]] developed by Michelson's UAV team at GTRI began as a traffic surveillance drone program.]] Michelson directed various efforts pertaining to future transportation. His team invented battery-state-of-charge estimation techniques, developed electric vehicle systems simulation tools, and experimented with actively blown surfaces on passenger vehicles. During the mid-1990s, Michelson's research began to focus almost entirely on unmanned vehicle systems, especially those with the power of flight. He directed efforts with both U.S. Government agencies and private industry pertaining to unmanned aerial vehicles systems (UAS). One of his first UAS development programs was for a traffic surveillance drone using a compound [[ducted fan]] design, made to fly over Atlanta's highways in order to fill surveillance gaps in the State's tower-mounted traffic camera system. It also could be sent to traffic accident locations to gather and relay vital information in advance of first-responder arrival. Funding shortfalls resulted in the cancellation of the project before its maiden flight, but the design was later marketed for military use. Michelson's focus turned to smaller vehicle systems that could fly indoors autonomously without the aid of [[global positioning system]] (GPS) reference signals. Under various contracts to DARPA and the Air Force, and using internal research and development funds from the Georgia Tech Research Institute, his design team designed a micro air vehicle (MAV) known as the [[entomopter]]. The NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts recognized the unique flight qualities of the entomopter and awarded Michelson two contracts to explore the feasibility of the entomopter for slow flight in Mars' lower atmosphere.{{cite book | last = Michelson | first = Robert |author2=A. Colozza |author3=K.A. Ahuja |author4=R.A. Englar | title = Planetary Exploration Using Biomimetics - ''An Entomopter for Flight on Mars'' | publisher = Georgia Institute of Technology | date = October 2002 | location = Atlanta, Georgia USA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = Phase II Final Report, NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts Project NAS5-98051 | isbn = |display-authors=etal}} In 2004 Michelson retired from the Georgia Tech Research Institute and started Millennial Vision, LLC which continued to pursue UAS and MAV research. Soon after establishing Millennial Vision, LLC, Michelson became engaged in a program to develop an unmanned stratospheric airship for persistent reconnaissance. He also was interested in MAVs and competitions by helping to define and organize various international events such as the 1st US-European MAV event in Garmisch Germany (MAV-05) and the subsequent 1st US-Asian Demonstration and Assessment of Micro Aerial Vehicle and Unmanned Ground Vehicle Technology (MAV-08) held in Agra India, as adjunct to the U.S. Army RDECOM-Pacific and Indian Ministry of Defence. [[File:Michelson interviewing Petter Muren at MAV-05.png|thumb|right|200px|Prof. Michelson interview with [[Petter Muren]] (holding MAV) at MAV-05 in Garmisch Germany.]] ===Associate professor of Aerospace Engineering=== During the 1990s, Michelson became an [[Adjunct professor#Adjunct professor|adjunct]] associate professor in the Georgia Tech School of Aerospace Engineering, where he taught graduate classes in avionics, with emphasis on unmanned aerial vehicles and micro air vehicles.{{cite news|url=http://gtri.wikispaces.com/file/view/AvionicsCourseOutline.pdf |title=Avionics Course Outline |accessdate=2010-06-08}}{{cite news|url=http://gtri.wikispaces.com/file/view/MAVCourseOutline.pdf |title=MAV Course Outline |accessdate=2010-06-08}} In parallel with his teaching duties in the Georgia Tech School of Aerospace Engineering, Michelson created a team-taught short course through the Georgia Tech Department of Continuing Education entitled, "21st Century Aerial Robotics". Laurence "Nuke" Newcome and Michelson taught this course on the campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology for several years before engaging in single offerings around the United States as well as Sweden, Norway, and Turkey under NATO grants.http://angel-strike.com/documents/RTO_Consultant_Norway.pdf NATO RTO consultancy plan for FFI/KA Norwayhttp://angel-strike.com/documents/Consultant_Exchange_Approval_Ltr_Michelson.pdf NATO Consultant Exchange Approval - HHO Turkey ==Honors and awards== Michelson is an Associate Fellow of the [[American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics]] (AIAA),{{cite news|title=What's Up in the Atlanta Section|work=(AIAA Newsletter - Atlanta Section)|date=November 2004|volume= Volume 30, No. 2, page 7}}{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/AIAA-Atlantanews2004_11.pdf|title=Atlanta Section - 11-04 AIAA Newsletter|accessdate=2009-03-22}} Senior Member of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]] (IEEE),{{cite news |url=http://www.ieee.org/portal/site/tionline/menuitem.130a3558587d56e8fb2275875bac26c8/index.jsp?&pName=institute_level1_article&TheCat=2201&article=tionline/legacy/inst2006/oct06/fstudents.xml&;jsessionid=hLjyJFBWvzWYp1y1XcTQJbqLXnGvJdnDVKDQsJ0YRQwjXvL7rwGx!-592835027!1129711250 |title=No Pilots, No Problem: Students Build Autonomous Aircraft |work=IEEE The Institute |date=October 7, 2006 |author=Jason Laday |accessdate=2014-07-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629103733/http://www.ieee.org/portal/site/tionline/menuitem.130a3558587d56e8fb2275875bac26c8/index.jsp?&pName=institute_level1_article&TheCat=2201&article=tionline%2Flegacy%2Finst2006%2Foct06%2Ffstudents.xml&%3Bjsessionid=hLjyJFBWvzWYp1y1XcTQJbqLXnGvJdnDVKDQsJ0YRQwjXvL7rwGx%21-592835027%211129711250 |archivedate=June 29, 2011 |df= }} and a Full Member of the [[Sigma Xi|Scientific Research Society of North America, Sigma Xi]]. During the 1990s he served as President and member of the Board of Directors of the [[Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International (AUVSI)|Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems (AUVSI)]] International organization.{{cite book | last = Nyquist | first = John E. | title = Application of Low-Cost Radio-Controlled Airplanes to Environmental Restoration at Oak Ridge National Laboratory | conference = CONF-9607137-2, Contract No. DE-AC05-96OR22464 | publisher = U.S. Department of Energy | date = September 13, 1996 | location = (also accessible on the internet at: http://www.osti.gov/bridge/servlets/purl/382992-eMTzP0/webviewable/382992.pdf [Accessed 2-17-09]) | volume = | pages = 14 | isbn = }} In 1998 Michelson received the AUVSI Pioneer Award {{cite news|title=AUVSI Honors Industry Leaders: Pioneer Award-Robert Michelson|work=Unmanned Systems (the Magazine of the Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International)|date=Summer 1998|volume= Volume 16, No. 3, page 22}} which is the highest level of recognition within the unmanned systems industry for technical contributions. Michelson is the recipient of the 2001 [[Pirelli Internetional Award|Pirelli Award]] for the diffusion of scientific culture,{{cite news|url=http://www.gtri.gatech.edu/files/GTRI-Annual-Report-2002.pdf|title=2002 GTRI Annual Report (on line pdf), page 3 ref. to Michelson winning Pirelli Award|accessdate=2009-03-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513025628/http://www.gtri.gatech.edu/files/GTRI-Annual-Report-2002.pdf|archivedate=2008-05-13|df=}} given by an international jury for the "best multimedia project coming from any educational institution in the world". For endeavors related to the [[entomopter]], he was also awarded the first €25,000 ''Top [[Pirelli]] Prize''.{{cite news|url=http://www.pirelliaward.com/ed6_edf.html |title=Education Section and Pirelli Top Prize |date=2002-05-10 |accessdate=2014-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208134956/http://www.pirelliaward.com/ed6_edf.html |archivedate=February 8, 2012 }} In 2016, the International Aerial Robotics Competition and its creator, Michelson, were officially recognized during the Georgia legislative session in the form of "Senate Resolution 1255” which recognized his effort in the development of the longest running aerial robotics competition in the world and for having been responsible for moving forward the state of the art in aerial robotics on several occasions during the past quarter century.{{cite news|url=http://www.angel-strike.com/documents/Senate_Resolution_1255.jpg|title= Senate Resolution 1255|accessdate=2016-07-25}} ==Avocations== Michelson has engaged in marine aquarium design and coral propagation since 1997 when he designed and built a fully automated marine reef biome, in which he propagated various coral species that he collected himself. He has been a [[National Association of Underwater Instructors|NAUI]] certified SCUBA diver since 1969, and has been a recreational diver in the Caribbean Sea and Pacific Ocean, where he dived on various wrecks and developed methods of collecting and successfully transporting marine invertebrates for propagation.{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/aquarium/MICHELSONAquarium.html|title=325 gallon marine aquarium system built by Robert Michelson|accessdate=2009-03-20}} Michelson has also built and flown his own man-rated experimental rotorcraft. N8489B is a single seat gyrocopter for which Michelson is the [[FAA]] certified mechanic and pilot.{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/N8489B_Gyrocopter_Doc_S.pdf|title=Gyrocopter N8489B|accessdate=2009-03-20}}{{cite news|url=https://vimeo.com/71366081|title=in-flight movie of Gyrocopter N8489B|accessdate=2018-07-17|df=}} [[File:RCM-Gyrocopter.png|thumb|right|200px|Michelson flying experimental-rated gyrocopter at the Richard B. Russell Airport in Rome, Georgia.]] While working with ground penetrating radar for detection of urban gas leaks, road voids, and buried land mines at the Georgia Tech Research Institute, Michelson became interested in the use of high technology applications to archeology. Since 1995 he has organized half a dozen excursions into the military zone along the Turkish-Iranian border, often with Turkish military escort, to research ancient [[Ekistics|ekistical]] artifacts of the [[eastern Anatolia region]]{{cite news|url=http://angel-strike.com/sepdac/5MICHELSONArcheology.html|title=Recent Travels to the Iranian Frntier of Eastern Türkiye|accessdate=2009-03-23}}{{cite news|url=http://www.angel-strike.com/sepdac/video.php|title=Planetary Catastrophe video series|accessdate=2017-07-15}} and has created a 501 (c3) non-profit corporation to apply various non-traditional technologies to the field of archeology.{{cite news|url=http://corporations.angel-strike.com/SEPDAC.html|title=Scientific Enterprise in Pursuit and Discovery of Ancient Cultures (SEPDAC)|accessdate=2009-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628040624/http://corporations.angel-strike.com/SEPDAC.html|archivedate=2009-06-28|df=}} Michelson completed training in general contracting/home building in 1986 and built his own home. Later he was overseer for the construction of a Woodstock Georgia church building while continuing his career at the Georgia Tech Research Institute.{{cite news|url=http://house.angel-strike.com/homebrochure/YourNewHome.pdf|title=Built own home|accessdate=2017-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224142/http://house.angel-strike.com/homebrochure/YourNewHome.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}} In 2013 he completed a home of his own design in the mountains of North Georgia that was lumber-free, consisting entirely of steel structural members with concrete foundation and concrete exterior.{{cite news|url=http://house.angel-strike.com/homebrochure/steelhome.jpg|title=Michelson steel & concrete home design|accessdate=2017-07-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308125906/http://house.angel-strike.com/homebrochure/steelhome.jpg|archivedate=2016-03-08|df=}} Michelson was a Boy Scout and has maintained interest in scouting principles over the years. As a youth he attained Star rank in Troop 981 located in [[Alexandria Virginia]], and was inducted into the Order of the Arrow. He became a Brotherhood member of [[Scouting in Washington, D.C.|Amangamek Wipit]] Lodge 470, one of the largest lodges in the nation, and participated in activities such as the [[Philmont Scout Ranch|Philmont Scout Reservation]] (1967). Influenced by their father, both of Michelson's sons are Eagle Scouts with gold and silver [[Eagle Palm|palm]] awards. Michelson was adult advisor to [[Boy Scouts of America]] (BSA) [https://web.archive.org/web/20131220134108/http://troop8880.org/ Troop/Crew 8880]{{cite news|url=http://crew8880.org/info.php|title=Crew 8880 official web site|accessdate=2017-07-15|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224020846/http://crew8880.org/info.php|archivedate=2012-02-24|df=}} until its transition away from the BSA to becoming a [[Trail Life USA]] unit where Michelson remains in an advisory capacity. Michelson has had interest in languages and syntax both for computers and spoken communication. He was formally taught [[Fortran]] in undergraduate school and learned [[BASIC]], [[Forth (programming language)|Forth]], and various [[assembly language]]s on his own in support of his computer-based projects. He designed the target processing unit for the Army's Environment and Radar Operation Simulator (EROS) where it was necessary to design the hardware and coding language for a 10 MHz (100 ns cycle time) processor before such things were available in microprocessor form.{{cite book | last = Sjoberg | first =E.S. |author2=Michelson, R.C. | title = Environment and Radar Operation Simulator (invited paper) | publisher = Proceedings of the NAAG Panel XIV (EW) Group | date = January 1978 | location = Brussels, Belgium | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} {{cite book | last = Sjoberg | first =E.S. |author2=Cole, S.N. |author3=Michelson, R.C. | title = Environment and Radar Operation Simulator | publisher = Proceedings of the Sixteenth Annual U.S. Army Operation Research Symposium (AORS XVI) | date = 12–14 October 1977 | location = Fort Lee, Virginia USA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = |display-authors=etal}} {{cite book | last = Sjoberg | first =E.S. |author2=Cole, S.N. |author3=Michelson, R.C. |author4=Flynt, E.R. | title = Environment and Radar Operation Simulator | publisher = Georgia Tech Engineering Experiment Station | date = September 1977 | location = Atlanta, Georgia USA | pages = | url = | doi = | id = Contract ECOM-74-0272-F | isbn = |display-authors=etal}} As to spoken languages, he is fluent in English, and is proficient in both Spanish and Turkish. ==Presence in popular media and literature== [[File:Michelson&Alda at IARC.png|thumb|right|200px|Robert Michelson being interviewed by [[Alan Alda]] at the 1995 International Aerial Robotics Competition during the filming of Scientific American Frontiers.{{Scientific American Frontiers|11|9}}]] Michelson has been widely interviewed and quoted in print (e.g., [[Business Week]], [[Popular Mechanics]], [[Scientific American]], [[Chronicle of Higher Education]]), radio (e.g., [[National Public Radio]], [[Armed Forces Radio]], [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] radio syndicate), and on television (e.g., [[Scientific American Frontiers]], [[Discovery Channel]], [[CNN]], [[BBC]], and various [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]/[[CBS]]/[[NBC]]/[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliates).{{cite news|url= http://www.aerialroboticscompetition.org/media.php|title = Who's Following the Aerial Robotics Competition?| accessdate=2018-02-20}} Worldwide interest in robotics, and especially the robots of war, spawned a series of televised robotics programming about Michelson's work. A technical biography of Robert Michelson is the subject of episode 1008 of the television program ''Beyond Invention'', which chronicles a number of his research projects including [[unmanned aerial vehicles|UAV]] research, the [[International Aerial Robotics Competition]], the entomopter-based [[Mars]] surveyor, and his work with automated coral propagation.{{cite episode |title = Artificial Intelligence - Episode 1008 |url = http://www.mystiquefilms.com/docs/beyond_overview.html |series = "Beyond Invention" |serieslink = Beyond Invention |credits = Christian Bruyere & Peter von Puttkamer, Producers; Mystique Films |network = |station = |airdate = 2003-11-17 |minutes = |transcripturl = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120529114310/http://www.mystiquefilms.com/docs/beyond_overview.html |archivedate = 2012-05-29 |df = }} Michelson is featured in various television programs focused specifically on the [[International Aerial Robotics Competition]], including an hour-long Discovery Science Channel program entitled ''Airbots''.{{cite episode | title = Airbots | url = http://www.robots.org/Airbots.htm | series = "Discovery Science Channel" | serieslink = Science Channel | credits = Rex Humbard, Prod., Advanced Media LLC.; Brian Natwick, Exec. Prod., Discovery Communications (see http://www.hirsh.tv/experience.asp) | network = | station = | airdate = 2001-02-18 | minutes = | transcripturl= }} Michelson has been often quoted in news programming with regard to the [[International Aerial Robotics Competition]] and the applications of the underlying technology to military and civilian spheres.{{cite episode | title=KEPR Evening News | url = http://www.keprtv.com/ | series = 1 | serieslink = | credits = CBS Channel 19 - Collette Keel, reporter | network = CBS | station = [[KEPR-TV]] | location = Richland, Pasco, and Kennewick Washington | airdate = 1998-08-14 | minutes = | transcripturl= }}{{cite episode | title = KVEW Evening News | url = http://www.kvewtv.com/ | series = 1 | serieslink = | credits = ABC Channel 42 - Tao McKay, reporter | network = ABC | station = [[KVEW]] | location = Richland, Pasco, and Kennewick Washington | airdate = 1998-08-14 | minutes = | transcripturl= }} As the use of robotic drone aircraft increased during the Gulf Wars, public interest in the subject was peaked and Michelson began to be featured in series and specials such as the [[Nova (TV series)|NOVA]] episode "Spies that Fly"{{cite episode | title = Spies that Fly | url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/spiesfly/about.html | series = NOVA | serieslink = | credits = WGBH, Boston | network = PBS | station = | airdate = 2003-01-07 | minutes = | transcripturl= }} and the [[BBC]] special ''Seven Ways to Topple Saddam''.{{cite episode | title = Seven Ways to Topple Saddam | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2003/01_january/24/iraq_day.shtml | series = Ron Liddle documentary; programme number: 01/ANC Z591Y | serieslink = | credits = | network = BBC | station = TWO | location = United Kingdom | airdate = 2003-01-26 | minutes = | transcripturl= }} Because of the notoriety of his aerial robotic research, Michelson even became the basis for the fictional character Michael C. Robertson in the novel ''Soft Target: The Air'' (2007) by Joel Narlock.{{cite news|title=Soft Target: The Air|last=Narlock|first=Joel|work=Dan River Press/Conservatory of American Letters, {{ISBN|0-89754-227-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-89754-227-2}}, 304 pages|date=2007-07-20|accessdate=2007-08-28|url=http://www.joelnarlock.com/media.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007165718/http://www.joelnarlock.com/media.html|archivedate=2007-10-07|df=}} In this work, Michael C. Robertson is the creator of the entomopter at the Georgia Technology Research Institute. This fictitious character's name is an [[anagram]] of Robert C. Michelson, the actual inventor of the entomopter at the Georgia ''Tech'' Research Institute. Michelson's entomopter is also featured in another of Joel Narlock's novels, ''Target Acquired'' (2003).{{cite news|title=Target Acquired|last=Narlock|first=Joel|work=Dorchester Publishing Co., Inc., {{ISBN|0-8439-5287-3}}, 340 pages|date=2003-10-01|accessdate=2009-03-20|url=http://www.dorchesterpub.com/Dorch/authordetail.cfm?Author_ID=184|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217130545/http://dorchesterpub.com/Dorch/authordetail.cfm?Author_ID=184|archivedate=2009-02-17|df=}} ==Patents== * {{US patent reference| inventor = Robert C. Michelson| title = Entomopter and Method for Using Same| number = 6,082,671| m= 07 | d= 04| y= 2000| url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=18&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=6,082,671&OS=6,082,671&RS=6,082,671 }} * {{US patent reference| inventor = Robert C. Michelson|title = Battery State of Charge Detector with Rapid Charging Capability and Method| number = 6,094,033| m= 07| d= 25 | y = 2000 |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=88&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&s1=6,094,033&p=2&OS=6,094,033&RS=6,094,033}} * {{US patent reference| inventor = Robert C. Michelson| title = Reciprocating Chemical Muscle (RCM) and Method for Using Same| number = 6,446,909| m= 09| d= 10 | y= 2002 |url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=17&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=6,082,671&OS=6,082,671&RS=6,082,671}} ==Representative publications== *“Test and Evaluation for Fully Autonomous Micro Air Vehicles,” The ITEA Journal, December 2008, Volume 29, Number 4, ISSN 1054-0229 International Test and Evaluation Association, pp. 367–374 *“Very small flying machines,” 2006 Yearbook of Science & Technology, McGraw-Hill, New York, {{ISBN|0-07-146205-8}}, 2006, pp. 341–344 *“Novel Approaches to Miniature Flight Platforms,” Proceedings of the Institute of Mechanical Engineers, Vol. 218 Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering, Special Issue Paper 2004, pp. 363–373 *“Beyond Biologically Inspired Insect Flight,” von Karman Institute for Fluid Dynamics RTO/AVT Lecture Series on Low Reynolds Number Aerodynamics on Aircraft Including Applications in Emerging UAV Technology, Brussels Belgium, 24–28 November 2003 *“The Entomopter,” Neurotechnology for Biomimetic Robots, {{ISBN|0-262-01193-X}}, The MIT Press, September 2002, pp. 481–509 *“Autonomous Vehicles,” Proceedings of the IEEE, Vol. 84, No. 8, August 1996, pp. 1147–1164 *“Feasibility of Applying Radio-Acoustic Techniques to Non Line-of-Sight Sensing,” AIAA Journal of Aircraft, Vol. 33, No. 2, March – April 1996, pp. 260–267 *“Tracking of the Florida Manatee,” ISA Transactions, Vol. 21, No. 1, 1982, pp. 79–85 ==See also== *[[Entomopter]] *[[International Aerial Robotics Competition]] *[[Micro air vehicle]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://angel-strike.com/rcmbio/RCM/MICHELSON.bio.html ''Curriculum Vitae'' of Robert C. Michelson] {{good article}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Michelson, Robert}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:American academics]] [[Category:21st-century American engineers]] [[Category:American patent holders]] [[Category:American people of Norwegian descent]] [[Category:American roboticists]] [[Category:Engineering educators]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:Georgia Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:Georgia Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Georgia Tech Research Institute people]] [[Category:Virginia Tech alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People associated with radar]] [[Category:Senior Members of the IEEE]] [[Category:Amateur radio people]] [[Category:People from Atlanta]]

'''Scott Gurvey''' is an American journalist and teacher.
He was for more than two decades the [[New York City]] Bureau Chief of the [[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS) [[television program]] ''[[Nightly Business Report]]''. He was also the program's [[technology]] [[reporter]] and wrote an [[Internet]]-based [[Column (newspaper)|column]] called "Public Offering." The program was sold to [[CNBC]].
Before joining ''Nightly Business Report'', Gurvey worked for [[CBS]] and [[NBC]]. He holds an [[undergraduate degree]] from [[Princeton University]] and two [[master's degrees]], one in [[journalism]] from [[Columbia University]] and another in [[Administration (business)|business administration]] from [[The University of Chicago]].
Born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], Gurvey is the son of Roy Gurvey, a former [[Chair (official)#Corporate governance|chairman]] and [[chief executive officer]] of [[The Dad's Root Beer Company]].
Gurvey now writes on business journalism for the [[Donald W. Reynolds National Center for Business Journalism]] at the [[Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication]] at [[Arizona State University]], where he has also been a guest lecturer. He also writes on technology for the Newsroom at [[Cisco Systems]].
Gurvey continues his blog at blog.scottgurvey.com.
==External links== * [http://blog.scottgurvey.com blog.scottgurvey.com] New site for blog
{{authority control}}

{{Other people|Faulkner|Faulkner (surname)}} {{Infobox person | name = Shannon Faulkner<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people supply only the year with {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} unless the exact date is already widely published, as per [[WP:DOB]]. For people who have died, use {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = [[Powdersville, South Carolina]], [[United States]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (DEATH date then BIRTH date) --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = First woman accepted into [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]] | notable_works = }} '''Shannon Faulkner''' is an [[United States|American]] educator and known for being the first woman admitted into [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]]. She currently teaches English in [[Greenville, South Carolina]].
== Biography == Faulkner was born in [[Powdersville, South Carolina]], [[United States]], graduated from [[Wren High School]] in January 1993.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Faulkner was angry that [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina|The Citadel]] would not allow women.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/11/magazine/the-citadel-s-lone-wolf-shannon-faulkner.html|title=The Citadel's Lone Wolf; Shannon Faulkner|last=Manegold;|first=Catherine S.|date=1994-09-11|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Faulkner became the first woman to attempt to enter the Corps of Cadets at The Citadel, which previously had a male-only admissions policy.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.postandcourier.com/politics/nancy-mace-pushes-back-after-shannon-faulkner-claims-to-be/article_5f9196a8-2093-11e8-8172-c3d50811c29c.html|title=Nancy Mace pushes back after Shannon Faulkner claims to be Citadel grad: 'She doesn't wear The Ring'|last=Byrd|first=Caitlin|date=|work=Post and Courier|access-date=2018-03-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=26 December 1994|title=Shannon Faulkner|url=http://people.com/archive/shannon-faulkner-vol-42-no-26/|journal=People|volume=42|issue=26|pages=58|via=}}</ref> Her application to the school was accompanied with having her gender blanked out of her high school transcripts.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1995/08/19/female-cadet-leaves-citadel/55865e22-83ed-4d08-865e-e52bb12cc983/|title=Female Cadet Leaves Citadel|last=Wilgoren|first=Debbi|date=1995-08-19|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Faulkner enrolled after a successful [[lawsuit]], ''Faulkner v. Jones et al.'', against the [[military academy]].<ref name="Kuersten">{{cite book|last=Kuersten|first=Ashlyn K.|title=Women and the law: leaders, cases, and documents|year=2003|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-87436-878-9|pages=72–73}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Bobrick|first=Elizabeth|date=June 2000|title=Arms and the Woman|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=3145488&site=ehost-live|journal=Women's Review of Books|volume=17|issue=9|pages=8|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> The suit alleged that the Citadel, which received state money, was "denying her equal protection under the [[Constitution]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1994/01/26/no-women-need-apply/4489ac98-982a-44f2-8221-86b710108989/|title=No Women Need Apply|last=MANN|first=JUDY|date=1994-01-26|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Her lawyer, Val Vojdik, said, "We are seeking educational opportunity... We are seeking equal access to a public program we pay for."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/05/17/trial-opens-in-womans-suit-to-join-citadels-corps-of-cadets/b5db41aa-71f9-489e-8249-38180f7ee13b/|title=Trial Opens in Woman's Suit to Join Citadel's Corps of Cadets|date=1994-05-17|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
Faulkner was allowed to attend classes as a day student by January 1994, but was not allowed to live on campus or wear the uniform.<ref name=":1" /> On campus, she was called "Mrs. Doubtgender" and faced other slurs from cadets.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/19/us/woman-at-citadel-tells-of-harassment.html|title=Woman at Citadel Tells of Harassment|date=1994-02-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> In 1994, [[Bumper sticker|bumper stickers]] appeared on cars in South Carolina that read "Shave Shannon," in an attempt to humiliate her.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/opinions/1994/08/06/shannon-faulkners-haircut/21082e53-5cb6-4191-9afa-5ef15c23f697/|title=Shannon Faulkner's Haircut|last=Goodman|first=Ellen|date=1994-08-06|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In August 1994, a judge ordered Faulkner to shave her head like the way the male Citadel students did each year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/08/02/judge-orders-female-cadet-to-shave-head-for-citadel/adec442a-9ac9-4011-99dd-c79d66fe7c5d/|title=Judge Orders Female Cadet to Shave Head for Citadel|last=Jordan|first=Mary|date=1994-08-02|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In 1995, T-shirts for sale appeared in Charleston reading "1,952 bulldogs and one bitch."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/07/23/citadel-ordered-to-admit-woman/5c699301-ac47-457f-898f-6c4a584d3cf2/|title=Citadel Ordered to Admit Woman|last=Jordan|first=Mary|date=1994-07-23|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> In July 1995, Faulkner and a federal judge, [[Charles Weston Houck|C. Weston Houck]], toured the woman's college that the state of South Carolina wanted to open as an alternative for women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=MacLachlan|first=Suzanne|last2=Mutch|first2=David|date=5 July 1995|title=Shannon Faulkner, toured the women's college|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=9507130092&site=ehost-live|journal=Christian Science Monitor|volume=87|issue=153|pages=2|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1995/06/08/citadel-segregation-plan-is-rejected/2cdba304-beed-4dc0-8a36-e7e748ee5709/|title=Citadel Segregation Plan is Rejected|date=1995-06-08|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Later that July, the same federal judge ruled that she should be admitted fully to The Citadel, and The Citadel planned to appeal the decision.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanson|first=Cynthia|last2=McLaughlin|first2=Abraham|date=26 July 1995|title=Shannon Faulkner is set to become the first female cadet|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=9508144763&site=ehost-live|journal=Christian Science Monitor|volume=87|issue=168|pages=2|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> In 1995, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled that Faulkner must be fully admitted.<ref name=":2" /> During the time she fought The Citadel in court, she "endured taunts and [[Death threat|death threats]]."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=28 August 1995|title=Shannon Faulkner|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=mih&AN=9508257539&site=ehost-live|journal=U.S. News & World Report|volume=119|issue=9|pages=28|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> She was also called "Shrew Shannon" by The Citadel's newspaper, and the article was dismissed by the president of The Citadel, [[Claudius E. Watts III|Claudius Watts]], as "satire."<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" />
Faulkner matriculated into The Citadel with an otherwise all-male corps of cadets on August 15, 1995 under the escort of [[United States Marshals]]. After only four hours of initial training, she suffered [[Hyperthermia|heat-stress]].<ref name=":3" /> She was one of five cadets who became ill.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McLaughlin|first=Abraham|date=16 August 1995|title=Five cadets--including Shannon Faulkner|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=9509100713&site=ehost-live|journal=Christian Science Monitor|volume=87|issue=183|pages=2|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> She spent the remainder of the first week in the infirmary before voluntarily resigning, citing emotional and psychological abuse and physical exhaustion.<ref name=":5" /> After her departure, the male cadets openly celebrated on the campus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/vaw00/Case%20Study%201%20Optional.html|title=Case Study 1: Shannon Faulkner and the Citadel|publisher=Harvard.edu|accessdate=30 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/shannon-faulkner-reflects-citadel/story?id=9272864|title=First Female Cadet at the Citadel Looks Back|last=Chang|first=Juju|last2=Sintay|first2=Liz|date=2009-12-08|website=ABC News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-07|last3=Clarke|first3=Suzan}}</ref> She told [[Oprah Winfrey]] on her show that she had gained weight during the court trials due to the stress she was facing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/09/10/us/citadel-s-first-female-cadet-tells-of-the-stress-of-her-court-fight.html|title=Citadel's First Female Cadet Tells of the Stress of Her Court Fight|date=1995-09-10|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> [[Diana Nyad]] criticized Faulkner for gaining weight and for not being fully prepared for training.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=6XN199508221113&site=ehost-live|title=Shannon Faulkner Criticized For Drop Out|last=Nyad|first=Diana|date=22 August 1995|work=Morning Edition (NPR)|access-date=8 March 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}}</ref> Faulkner was one of thirty cadets to drop out.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/22/opinion/sadness-and-shame-at-the-citadel.html|title=Sadness and Shame at The Citadel|date=1995-08-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
Two decades later, in a 2012 interview with the ''[[The Post and Courier|Post and Courier]]'' newspaper, Faulkner said that what precipitated her leaving so abruptly was a threat to kill her parents by a person present when she entered.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/archives/where-is-shannon-now/article_0d2b52b1-86c6-5165-9168-bd6bea0dbd4b.html|title=Where is Shannon Now|last=Hawes|first=Jennifer|date=October 19, 2012|work=the Post and Courier|access-date=June 17, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Her parent's home was [[Vandalism|vandalized]].<ref name=":5" /> In 1999, she told the ''[[Associated Press]]'', "I went into it knowing I may not get anything out of it. I was doing it for the next woman."<ref name=":6" />
Writer [[Pat Conroy]] paid for Faulkner's education after she left the Citadel, and she became a middle school teacher in South Carolina.<ref name="Chang">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/shannon-faulkner-reflects-citadel/story?id=9272864|title=Life After the Citadel: Shannon Faulkner Reflects on Her Historic Battle with the Elite Military College|last=Chang|first=Juju |author2=Liz Sintay |author3=Suzan Clarke |date=8 December 2009|publisher=ABC News.com - Good Morning America|accessdate=30 September 2010}}</ref> Faulkner attended [[Anderson University (South Carolina)|Anderson College]].<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/aponline/19991017/aponline142025_000.htm|title=Shannon Faulkner Teaching English|last=|first=|date=17 October 1999|website=Washington Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-08}}</ref> After graduating in 1999, she was hired by Carolina High School.<ref name=":6" />
In August 1996, four women were admitted to The Citadel.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1996/12/14/2-citadel-women-say-cadets-set-fire-to-clothes/506a9d23-d0fa-4564-84f3-572dfb750801/|title=2 Citadel Women Say Cadets Set Fire to ClothesS|last=Pressley|first=Sue Anne|date=1996-12-14|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> By December 2009, The Citadel had graduated 205 female cadets since Faulkner's admission.<ref name=":4" /> In March 2018, Faulkner returned to The Citadel as an invited speaker at a symposium about Conroy.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.postandcourier.com/news/shannon-faulkner-says-i-do-consider-myself-a-citadel-alumni/article_2a51c556-1e47-11e8-beea-4f0b27568b0c.html |title= Shannon Faulkner says, 'I do consider myself a Citadel alumni' during her historic return |work=[[The Post and Courier]] |date=March 3, 2018 |accessdate=2018-03-06 }}</ref> Her statement that she would not criticize the school and considers herself "a Citadel alumni" drew a sharp attack from state representative [[Nancy Mace]], who was the first woman to graduate from The Citadel in 1999.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.live5news.com/story/37649311/nancy-mace-fires-back-at-shannon-faulkner-after-saturday-event-at-the-citadel |title=Nancy Mace fires back at Shannon Faulkner after Saturday event at The Citadel |work=[[WCSC-TV]] |date=March 5, 2018 |accessdate=2018-03-06 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.live5news.com/story/37658992/citadel-alumni-express-frustration-with-shannon-faulkners-speech-on-saturday|title=Citadel alumni express frustration with Shannon Faulkner's speech on Saturday|last=Streicher|first=Brad|access-date=2018-03-07|language=en}}</ref>
Faulkner is currently an English teacher in [[Greenville, South Carolina|Greenville]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/faulkner-says-she-considers-herself-an-alumni-of-the-citadel/2018/03/04/d7e3706e-1fe3-11e8-946c-9420060cb7bd_story.html|title=1st woman to enter The Citadel talks about brief time there|date=2018-03-04|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-03-08|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> and pursuing a graduate degree at [[Southern Wesleyan University]]
==In popular culture== Faulkner is mentioned indirectly in the ''[[King of the Hill]]'' episode "Jumpin' Crack Bass". In the episode, she is referred to as "that pushy gal who's tryin' to get into The Citadel".
[[Garry Shandling]] makes reference to Faulkner in Season 4, Episode 8 of ''[[The Larry Sanders Show]]'', entitled "Nothing Personal".
[[Lisa Simpson]]'s experience in ''[[The Simpsons]]''' 8th-season finale, ''[[The Secret War of Lisa Simpson]]'', broadly resembles Faulkner's.<ref name="Henry2012">{{cite book|author=Matthew A. Henry|title=The Simpsons, Satire, and American Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HSVeAQAAQBAJ&pg=PT161|year=2012|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-137-02779-5|pages=161–163}}</ref>
==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}}
;Bibliography {{refbegin}} *''In the Company of Men: A Woman at The Citadel (Simon Pulse:Reprint edition 2002)'' by [[Nancy Mace]], the first woman to graduate from [[The Citadel (Military College)|The Citadel]]. *''In Glory's Shadow : The Citadel, Shannon Faulkner, and a Changing America (Vintage:2001)'' by [[Catherine S. Manegold]]. {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,155748,00.html "Women Gain Ground at Citadel", Fox News] *[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1008555 1995 Interview] on [[NPR]]

{{for|the village in Iran|Sizan}} At [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]], [[University of Dublin|Dublin]] and the [[University of Cambridge]], a '''sizar''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|aɪ|z|ər}} is an [[Undergraduate education|undergraduate]] who receives some form of assistance such as meals, lower fees or lodging during his or her period of study, in some cases in return for doing a defined job. ==Etymology== The word is thought to derive from the "sizes" or "sizings" (in turn a shortened form of "[[assize]]"), which were the specified portions of food and drink made available at a fixed price at the college. One of the sizar's duties was, historically, to fetch the "sizes" for his colleagues. ==History== At Cambridge, a sizar was originally an undergraduate student who financed his studies by undertaking more or less menial tasks within his college but, as time went on, was increasingly likely to receive small grants from the college.{{cite web|title=Glossary: sizar|url=https://janus.lib.cam.ac.uk/db/node.xsp?id=Glossary%2Fsizar|website=janus.lib.cam.ac.uk|accessdate=10 January 2018}} Certain colleges, including [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity]], distinguished between two categories of sizar: there were specific endowments for specific numbers of sizars who were called "proper sizars", those who were not so endowed, but who were maintained by [[Commoner (academia)|fellow-commoner]]s and [[fellow]]s were called subsizars. [[Isaac Newton]] [[Matriculation|matriculated]] as subsizar at Trinity College.{{cite web |url=http://www.ngzh.ch/Neuj1972.html |title=Isaac Newton als Mathematiker |trans-title=Isaac Newton as a mathematician Markus Fierz |language=de |website=Naturforschende Gesellschaft in Zürich |accessdate=2013-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120906162848/http://www.ngzh.ch/Neuj1972.html |archivedate=2012-09-06 |df= }} [[Richard S. Westfall]] noted that sizars were considerably more successful in gaining degrees than the gentlemen who entered Cambridge in the seventeenth century. Whereas only 30% of the latter continued to the degree (and 68% of the sons of professionals), around 80% of the sons of tradesmen and [[yeomen]], who made up most of the sizars, took their degree. {{cite book|authorlink=Richard S. Westfall |last=Westfall |first=Richard S. |title=Never at Rest |page=75|publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1980 |isbn=0-521-27435-4|ref=harv }} [[Churchill College, Cambridge]] offers three sizarships per year, with the recipients being expected to promote music, theatre and the visual arts in the life of the college.{{cite web|title=Sizarships|url=https://www.chu.cam.ac.uk/student-hub/resources/financial-support/sizarships/|website=Churchill College|accessdate=10 January 2018}} According to ''Alumni Dublinenses'' from 1935,Alumni Dublinenses, Dublin, Alex. Thom & Co. Ltd., 2 Crown Street, 1935 most students entered Trinity College, Dublin as "pensioners"; in other words, they paid a fixed sum annually. The other two categories were "sizars" and "fellow commoners" (''Socii Comitates''). Sizars were "allowed free education in consideration of performing certain, at one time menial, duties"; fellow commoners paid double fees and enjoyed several privileges, including that of finishing the College course in three years instead of four; "sizars were sons of poor parents, frequently the clergy". According to [[William Howitt]], writing in 1847 with reference to [[Oliver Goldsmith]]:
Trinity College, Dublin, is a noble structure; and, with its spacious courts and extensive gardens, more fittingly deserving the name of parks, one would think a place where the years of studentship might — especially in the heart of such a city — be very agreeably spent. But Goldsmith entered there under circumstances that were irksome to him, and to add to the matter, he met with a brute in his tutor. The family income did not allow him to occupy a higher rank than that of a sizer, or poor scholar, and this was mortifying to his sensitive mind. The sizer wears a black gown of coarse stuff without sleeves, a plain black cloth cap without a tassel, and dines at the fellows' table after they have retired. It was at that period far worse; they wore red caps to distinguish them, and were compelled to perform derogatory offices; to sweep the courts in the morning, carry up the dishes from the kitchen to the fellows' table, and wait in the hall till they had dined. No wonder that a mind like that of Goldsmith's writhed under the degradation! He has recorded his own feelings and opinions on this custom: "Sure pride itself has dictated to the fellows of our colleges the absurd fashion of being attended at meals, and on other public occasions, by those poor men who, willing to be scholars, come in upon some charitable foundation. It implies a contradiction, for men to be at once learning the liberal arts and at the same time treated as slaves; at once studying freedom and practising servitude." A spirited fellow at length caused the abolition of the practice of the sizers acting as waiters, and that, too, on grand occasions before the public, by flinging the dish he was carrying on [[Trinity Sunday]], at the head of a citizen in the crowd, assembled to witness the scene, who made some jeering remarks on the office he had to perform.William Howitt, "Oliver Goldsmith" Homes and Haunts of the Most Eminent British Poets (1847) 1:286–336.
Sizarships are still awarded at Dublin, to new entrants of limited means who have shown merit in their school-leaving examinations. They receive their evening meal ([[Commons]]) free of charge, normally for the first two years of an undergraduate course. The word ''sizarship'' is also still used elsewhere to refer to monetary awards made to members of a student body willing to take on defined jobs with responsibility; according to [[John Stillwell]], "Sizars had to earn their keep as servants to the wealthier students [...]".{{cite book |last=Stillwell |first=John |authorlink= |coauthors= |editor=S. Axler |editor2=F. W. Gehring |editor3=K. A. Ribet |others= |title=Mathematics and Its History |origyear=1989 |month= |url= |edition=2nd |series=[[Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics]] |volume= |date= |year=2002 |publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] New York |location=New York |language= |isbn=0-387-95336-1 |pages=163 |chapter=Calculus [sub-chapter 9.7 Biographical Notes: Wallis, Newton, and Leibniz] |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=WNjRrqTm62QC&pg=PA163 |quote=Sizars had to earn their keep as servants to wealthier students [...] |ref= }} ==See also== * [[Servitor]] * [[Batteler]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wiktionary}} * {{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Sizar |volume=25 |page=165 |short=x}} [[Category:Academic culture]] [[Category:Trinity College, Dublin]] [[Category:Terminology of the University of Cambridge]]

{{Multiple| {{COI|date=March 2018}} {{tone|date=March 2018}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Use British English|date=February 2012}} [[File:Stephen Farthing.png|thumb|Stephen Farthing in 2009]] '''Stephen Farthing''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|RA}} (born 16 September 1950) is an English painter and writer on [[art history]].
==Education== Stephen Farthing grew up in London and earned a bachelor's degree from [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] in 1973 and a master's degree in painting from the [[Royal College of Art]], London in 1976.<ref name="royalacademy1">{{cite web|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/academicians/painters/stephen-farthing-ra,175,AR.html |title=Stephen Farthing RA - Painters - Royal Academicians - Royal Academy of Arts |publisher=Royalacademy.org.uk |date=1950-09-16 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> In the final year of his master's program, Farthing won a scholarship to study at the [[British School in Rome]] for one year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.purdyhicks.com/artists/stephenfarthing/ |title=Purdy Hicks Artists Index |publisher=Purdyhicks.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref>
==Life and career== Since his return from Italy in 1977, Farthing has had one-man shows in the UK, Brazil, Uruguay, Mexico, Australia, Japan, and the United States.<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing's work featured in the 1989 [[São Paulo Art Biennial|São Paulo Biennale]] and that same year he served as the Artist in Residence at the [[Hayward Gallery]] in London. He also won prizes in the John Moores Liverpool Exhibition on eight separate occasions between 1976 and 1999.<ref name="royalacademy1"/>
Farthing was elected as a member of the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] in 1998.<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing's work is in the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)]] and he also showed at the [[Tate Britain]] in 2006 as part of a project called "Drawing from Turner," that he designed and curated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/exhibitions/drawingfromturner/ |title=Drawing from Turner |publisher=Tate |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> Farthing also painted large murals for the [[Cleveland Browns]] Football Club in Cleveland, Ohio (2004) and [[Aston Villa]] Football Club in Birmingham, UK (2008).<ref>http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~1405273,00.html</ref><ref name="Stephen Farthing">{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/marco.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193759/http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/marco.htm |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Stephen Farthing's teaching career began at [[Canterbury College of Art]] (1977–1979) where he was a lecturer of painting. He went on to teach at the [[Royal College of Art]] (1980–1985) before becoming the Head of Painting and later the Head of Fine Art at [[West Surrey College of Art and Design]] (1985–1989).<ref name="royalacademy1"/> Farthing spent the next ten years at [[Oxford University]] serving as the Ruskin Master at the [[Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art]]. He was also made a Professorial Fellow of Oxford's [[St Edmund Hall]] (1990–2000). Upon leaving the university in 2000, Farthing was made a professor emeritus of St Edmund Hall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seh.ox.ac.uk/users/stephenfarthing |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Seh.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-04-10}}</ref>
Farthing moved to New York in 2000 to become the Executive Director of the [[New York Academy of Art]] and led the Academy until he became the Rootstein Hopkins Research Chair of Drawing at the [[University of the Arts London]] in 2004, a position he held until 2017.<ref name="chelsea.arts.ac.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.arts.ac.uk/research/research-staff/a-z/professor-stephen-farthing/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413150046/http://www.arts.ac.uk/research/research-staff/a-z/professor-stephen-farthing/ |archivedate=13 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Farthing has published extensively. Most known for his authorship of ''1001 Paintings You Must See Before You Die'' and ''501 Great Artists''. He also authored the Intelligent Person's Guide to Modern Art, published in 2000 in addition to numerous academic essays and journal articles.<ref name="chelsea.arts.ac.uk"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/biblio.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208064936/http://stephenfarthing.com/biblio.htm |archivedate=8 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Stephen Farthing continues to live and work in both the United Kingdom and the United States.
==Work== [[File:Step9.gif|thumb|alt=Stephen Farthing.|''Louis XV Rigaud'' (1975), [[Walker Art Gallery]]]]''
Farthing described his work in a 2005 interview, saying "I have dined with the devil in terms of becoming a modern artist. I have taken hold of history, tried to understand it—and then used and abused it."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=196599&sectioncode=26 |title=Draw the line at copying? Not him | General |publisher=Times Higher Education |date=2005-06-10 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref>
Farthing's work reflects his education, personal experience and perspective on historical events that have captured his imagination. After spending a period of study at the Cité Internationale des Arts in Paris while a student at the [[Royal College of Art]], Stephen Farthing inadvertently fell upon what one could later describe as a postmodernist relationship with history.<ref>Randy Lerner, "The Fourth Wall," in Stephen Farthing: The Fourth Wall, London: Purdy Hicks, 2009, p. 5.</ref> In Paris, he painted an interpretation of [[Hyacinthe Rigaud]]'s portrait of [[Louis XV]] that as a student won him a prize at the John Moores Exhibition in Liverpool, today this painting stands as an early example of British post modernist painting.<ref name="Stephen Farthing"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/20c/farthing.aspx |title='Louis XV Rigaud', Stephen Farthing - Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool museums |publisher=Liverpoolmuseums.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228131607/http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/20c/farthing.aspx |archivedate=28 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In the late 1980s and early 1990s whilst showing with Edward Totah in London, Farthing showed works that positioned Latin American vernacular culture within a modernist idiom and classicism within the vernacular.
During the 1990s, he reinvented history painting as a viable contemporary narrative taking on subject matters as diverse as the [[Battle of Trafalgar]], swagger portraiture, and the topographical mapping of cities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/mcewan.htm |title=Stephen Farthing |publisher=Stephen Farthing |date= |accessdate=2013-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193821/http://www.stephenfarthing.com/writing/mcewan.htm |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/122406/pro_122406079.shtml |title=Cleveland Browns owner getting his kicks from English football | Lubbock Online | Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |publisher=Lubbock Online |date=2006-12-24 |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> His most recent work makes explicit a theme that has consistently sat between Farthing and his audience, the "narrative" and "text".
[[File:MH.Trafalgar.2.20.06.jpg|thumb|center|upright=2.0|alt=Hands of Fate. |''Hands of Fate'', ([[Battle of Trafalgar]])]] [[File:GetAttachment-2.aspx.jpeg|thumb|left|alt=Stephen Farthing.|''The Backstory: Boucher'' (2009)]]
Farthing commented that his work is, "not this thing about 'Oh, let's let the audience make up their mind what it is'…" but about "degrading it on purpose so it becomes not more ambiguous, but less what it was in the first place."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lynnparr.co.uk/articles/Farthing.pdf|title=Stephen Farthing : Marginally Out of Control|publisher=Lynnparr.co.uk|accessdate=2013-11-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302193753/http://www.lynnparr.co.uk/articles/Farthing.pdf|archivedate=2 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Toward the end of 2009, Farthing had his first one-person show at the Purdy Hicks Gallery in London where, for the first time, he showed the "back-story" paintings.<ref>Randy Lerner, "The Fourth Wall," in Stephen Farthing: The Fourth Wall, London: Purdy Hicks, 2009, p. 7.</ref> The "back-story" paintings are a series of images painted with a text in reverse sitting on the picture plane between the audience and the image. The text tells us what is going on not in the picture but behind it, so compromising and at the same time informing the image with text. His technically very skilled paintings all seem to be grounded on one guiding principle - that what we see will always be always conditioned by what we know.
In November 2010, Farthing became the second living Royal Academician to be featured in the "laboratory" series of one man shows at the Royal Academy of Arts London. "The Back Story," featured an epic 30 foot painting of the Atlantic ocean.<ref>{{cite web|last=Royal Academy of Arts|title=Artists' Laboratory 02: Stephen Farthing RA, The Back Story|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/artists-laboratory/artists-laboratory-02-stephen-farthing-ra-the-back-story,342,RAL.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301044735/http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/artists-laboratory/artists-laboratory-02-stephen-farthing-ra-the-back-story,342,RAL.html|archivedate=1 March 2014|work=Press Release|accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chelsea Space|title=Stephen Farthing's Ultra Marine Painting|url=http://www.chelseaspace.org/blog/archives/272|work=Atlantic Ocean|accessdate=4 March 2011}}</ref>
Farthing's work as a painter sits midway between the conservative and the cutting edge between a classical and radical painting. [[File:Atlantic by Stephen Farthing.png|thumb|center|upright=2.0|alt=Atlantic.|''The Atlantic'' (2006), photographed at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], December 2010.]]

{{more references|date=October 2017}} {{Expand Spanish|Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid|date=March 2009}} {| border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" align="right" style="margin:0.5em;" !colspan="2" align=center bgcolor="#000099" | '''Superior Technical School
of Architecture of Madrid'''

(Technical University of Madrid, UPM)'''

|- !colspan="2" align=center bgcolor="#000099" | |- |Established || 1844 |- |Localization|| [[Madrid]] ([[Spain]]) |- |Address || Avenida Juan de Herrera, 4
28040 [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] |- |Telephone || +(34) 91 336 65 01 |- |Website || [http://www.aq.upm.es www.aq.upm.es] |- |} The '''Superior Technical School of Architecture of Madrid''' ({{lang-es|Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid}}, '''ETSAM''') is the superior school of [[architecture]] of the [[Technical University of Madrid]] (UPM), [[Spain]]. It prepares future architects and grants the title of [[Architect]], as well as doctorates and diverse master's degrees. The center is located on the ''Avenida Juan de Herrera'', 4, within the [[University City of Madrid]]. The present building has been used since 1936. It has an extensive library which includes original treaties of [[Le Corbusier]], [[Serlio]] and [[Andrés de Vandelvira]], the most recent magazines of architecture, the most influential books on modern architecture. This school is considered by many professionals of the sector as the best in Spain and one of the best worldwide. == Study plan == Currently the study plan followed in the center focused on the obtention of the main Architecture diploma is the plan 2010, also known as Bolonia. It was passed in the session celebrated in 2007 at the same school. From then on, the old ''Plan 96'' was slowly extincted, till June 2018. The 2010 Plan consists in 360 European credits ''ECTS'', with an equivalence of between 25 and 30 hours of work per credit, and started in 2010-2011. The 360 credits are split into a 300-credit degree and a 60-credit master, a formula known as 5+1 years. The degree is a 5 year study plan, with each year split in 2 different cuatrimesters, Fall and Spring. Subjects can be classified as Basic (shared with other faculties in UPM), compulsory or Optative (exclusively lectured at ETSAM). Only 18 credits correspond to Optative subjects. Once the programme is completed, the student receives a Graduate title in Architecture fundaments, which opens the way for the University Master in Architecture, (one year), which grants the full title of Architect. == Posgraduate Studies == The school grants different posgraduate studies, accesible only to those with the title of Architect. Studies at this level can be Phds or posgraduate. Phd Studies are organised in programs, each one of them having several subjects that jointly present unity and relationships, and together define a speciality inside the Phd studies. Posgraduate studies are divided into 9 University masters, 15 specialisation courses{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214041819/http://www.aq.upm.es/secretaria/tercer_ciclo/|title=[etsam]|date=2007-12-14|access-date=2018-06-12}} and 14 independent titles{{Cite web|url=http://etsamadrid.aq.upm.es/escuela/subdirecciones/posgrado/master_propio_programas|title=Subdirección de Doctorado y Posgrado {{!}} etsamadrid.upm.es|website=etsamadrid.aq.upm.es|language=es|access-date=2018-06-12}}. Many of them present an international level of prestige and influence, such as the Master in City Sciences{{Cite web|url=http://www.citysciences.com/|title=MASTER CITY SCIENCE - HOME|website=www.citysciences.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-12}} and the MCH Master in Collective Housing{{Cite web|url=https://www.mchmaster.com/|title=MCH: Master in Collective Housing|website=www.mchmaster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}. == Notable alumni == {{div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Carlos Arroyo (architect)|Carlos Arroyo]] Zapatero (born 1964) *[[Mariano Bayón]] (born 1942) *[[Alberto Campo Baeza]] (born 1946) *[[Félix Candela]] Outeriño (1910–1997) *[[María Francisca Lage de la Fuente]] (born 1954) *[[Andrés Jaque]] (born 1971) *[[Rafael Moneo]] Vallés (born 1937) *[[Manuel Martín Madrid]] (born 1938) *[[Juan Navarro Baldeweg]] (born 1939) *[[Antonio Palacios]] Ramilo (1872–1945) *[[Juan Herreros]] (born 1958) *[[Francisco Javier Sáenz de Oiza]] (1918–2000) *[[Manuel Sánchez Arcas]] (1897–1970) *[[Alejandro de la Sota]] Martínez (1913–1996) *[[Salvador Valeri i Pupurull]] (1873–1954) *[[Alejandro Zaera-Polo]] (born 1963) {{div col end}} == Gallery == Image:Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid - 02.jpg|Superior Technical School of Architecture of Madrid Image:ETSAM edificio nuevo.JPG|Inside the ''new building'' of the ETSAM. == References == == External links == {{Commons category|Escuela Técnica Superior de Arquitectura de Madrid|Superior Technical School of Architecture of Madrid}} *{{Es icon}} [http://www.aq.upm.es/ The official Website of Superior Technical School of Architecture of Madrid] [[Category:Technical University of Madrid]] [[Category:Architecture schools|Madrid]]
